text: They made many signs which I did not comprehend but I saw that her presence diffused gladness through the cottage dispelling their sorrow as the sun dissipates the morning mists.
author: MWS

text: Felix seemed peculiarly happy and with smiles of delight welcomed his Arabian.
author: MWS

text: Agatha the ever-gentle Agatha kissed the hands of the lovely stranger and pointing to her brother made signs which appeared to me to mean that he had been sorrowful until she came.
author: MWS

text: Some hours passed thus while they by their countenances expressed joy the cause of which I did not comprehend.
author: MWS

text: Presently I found by the frequent recurrence of some sound which the stranger repeated after them that she was endeavouring to learn their language; and the idea instantly occurred to me that I should make use of the same instructions to the same end.
author: MWS

text: The stranger learned about twenty words at the first lesson; most of them indeed were those which I had before understood but I profited by the others.
author: MWS

text: As night came on Agatha and the Arabian retired early.
author: MWS

text: When they separated Felix kissed the hand of the stranger and said Good night sweet Safie.
author: MWS

text: He sat up much longer conversing with his father and by the frequent repetition of her name I conjectured that their lovely guest was the subject of their conversation.
author: MWS

text: I ardently desired to understand them and bent every faculty towards that purpose but found it utterly impossible.
author: MWS

text: The next morning Felix went out to his work and after the usual occupations of Agatha were finished the Arabian sat at the feet of the old man and taking his guitar played some airs so entrancingly beautiful that they at once drew tears of sorrow and delight from my eyes.
author: MWS

text: She sang and her voice flowed in a rich cadence swelling or dying away like a nightingale of the woods.
author: MWS

text: When she had finished she gave the guitar to Agatha who at first declined it.
author: MWS

text: She played a simple air and her voice accompanied it in sweet accents but unlike the wondrous strain of the stranger.
author: MWS

text: The old man appeared enraptured and said some words which Agatha endeavoured to explain to Safie and by which he appeared to wish to express that she bestowed on him the greatest delight by her music.
author: MWS

text: The days now passed as peaceably as before with the sole alteration that joy had taken place of sadness in the countenances of my friends.
author: MWS

text: Safie was always gay and happy; she and I improved rapidly in the knowledge of language so that in two months I began to comprehend most of the words uttered by my protectors.
author: MWS

text: In the meanwhile also the black ground was covered with herbage and the green banks interspersed with innumerable flowers sweet to the scent and the eyes stars of pale radiance among the moonlight woods; the sun became warmer the nights clear and balmy; and my nocturnal rambles were an extreme pleasure to me although they were considerably shortened by the late setting and early rising of the sun for I never ventured abroad during daylight fearful of meeting with the same treatment I had formerly endured in the first village which I entered.
author: MWS

text: My days were spent in close attention that I might more speedily master the language; and I may boast that I improved more rapidly than the Arabian who understood very little and conversed in broken accents whilst I comprehended and could imitate almost every word that was spoken.
author: MWS

text: While I improved in speech I also learned the science of letters as it was taught to the stranger and this opened before me a wide field for wonder and delight.
author: MWS

text: The book from which Felix instructed Safie was Volneys Ruins of Empires.
author: MWS

text: I should not have understood the purport of this book had not Felix in reading it given very minute explanations.
author: MWS

text: He had chosen this work he said because the declamatory style was framed in imitation of the Eastern authors.
author: MWS

text: Through this work I obtained a cursory knowledge of history and a view of the several empires at present existing in the world; it gave me an insight into the manners governments and religions of the different nations of the earth.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the slothful Asiatics of the stupendous genius and mental activity of the Grecians of the wars and wonderful virtue of the early Romansof their subsequent degeneratingof the decline of that mighty empire of chivalry Christianity and kings.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the discovery of the American hemisphere and wept with Safie over the hapless fate of its original inhabitants.
author: MWS

text: Was man indeed at once so powerful so virtuous and magnificent yet so vicious and base  He appeared at one time a mere scion of the evil principle and at another as all that can be conceived of noble and godlike.
author: MWS

text: To be a great and virtuous man appeared the highest honour that can befall a sensitive being; to be base and vicious as many on record have been appeared the lowest degradation a condition more abject than that of the blind mole or harmless worm.
author: MWS

text: For a long time I could not conceive how one man could go forth to murder his fellow or even why there were laws and governments; but when I heard details of vice and bloodshed my wonder ceased and I turned away with disgust and loathing.
author: MWS

text: Every conversation of the cottagers now opened new wonders to me.
author: MWS

text: While I listened to the instructions which Felix bestowed upon the Arabian the strange system of human society was explained to me.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the division of property of immense wealth and squalid poverty of rank descent and noble blood.
author: MWS

text: I learned that the possessions most esteemed by your fellow creatures were high and unsullied descent united with riches.
author: MWS

text: A man might be respected with only one of these advantages but without either he was considered except in very rare instances as a vagabond and a slave doomed to waste his powers for the profits of the chosen few  And what was I Of my creation and creator I was absolutely ignorant but I knew that I possessed no money no friends no kind of property.
author: MWS

text: I was besides endued with a figure hideously deformed and loathsome; I was not even of the same nature as man.
author: MWS

text: I was more agile than they and could subsist upon coarser diet; I bore the extremes of heat and cold with less injury to my frame; my stature far exceeded theirs.
author: MWS

text: When I looked around I saw and heard of none like me.
author: MWS

text: Was I then a monster a blot upon the earth from which all men fled and whom all men disowned  I cannot describe to you the agony that these reflections inflicted upon me; I tried to dispel them but sorrow only increased with knowledge.
author: MWS

text: Oh that I had for ever remained in my native wood nor known nor felt beyond the sensations of hunger thirst and heat  Of what a strange nature is knowledge  It clings to the mind when it has once seized on it like a lichen on the rock.
author: MWS

text: I wished sometimes to shake off all thought and feeling but I learned that there was but one means to overcome the sensation of pain and that was deatha state which I feared yet did not understand.
author: MWS

text: I admired virtue and good feelings and loved the gentle manners and amiable qualities of my cottagers but I was shut out from intercourse with them except through means which I obtained by stealth when I was unseen and unknown and which rather increased than satisfied the desire I had of becoming one among my fellows.
author: MWS

text: The gentle words of Agatha and  the animated smiles of the charming Arabian were not for me.
author: MWS

text: The mild exhortations of the old man and the lively conversation of the loved Felix were not for me.
author: MWS

text: Miserable unhappy wretch  Other lessons were impressed upon me even more deeply.
author: MWS

text: I heard of the difference of sexes and the birth and growth of children how the father doted on the smiles of the infant and the lively sallies of the older child how all the life and cares of the mother were wrapped up in the precious charge how the mind of youth expanded and gained knowledge of brother sister and all the various relationships which bind one human being to another in mutual bonds.
author: MWS

text: But where were my friends and relations  No father had watched my infant days no mother had blessed me with smiles and caresses; or if they had all my past life was now a blot a blind vacancy in which I distinguished nothing.
author: MWS

text: From my earliest remembrance I had been as I then was in height and proportion.
author: MWS

text: I had never yet seen a being resembling me or who claimed any intercourse with me.
author: MWS

text: What was I  The question again recurred to be answered only with groans.
author: MWS

text: I will soon explain to what these feelings tended but allow me now to return to the cottagers whose story excited in me such various feelings of indignation delight and wonder but which all terminated in additional love and reverence for my protectors for so I loved in an innocent half-painful self-deceit to call them.
author: MWS

text: Some time elapsed before I learned the history of my friends.
author: MWS

text: It was one which could not fail to impress itself deeply on my mind unfolding as it did a number of circumstances each interesting and wonderful to one so utterly inexperienced as I was.
author: MWS

text: He was descended from a good family in France where he had lived for many years in affluence respected by his superiors and beloved by his equals.
author: MWS

text: His son was bred in the service of his country and Agatha had ranked with ladies of the highest distinction.
author: MWS

text: A few months before my arrival they had lived in a large and luxurious city called Paris surrounded by friends and possessed of every enjoyment which virtue refinement of intellect or taste accompanied by a moderate fortune could afford.
author: MWS

text: The father of Safie had been the cause of their ruin.
author: MWS

text: He was a Turkish merchant and had inhabited Paris for many years when for some reason which I could not learn he became obnoxious to the government.
author: MWS

text: He was seized and cast into prison the very day that Safie arrived from Constantinople to join him.
author: MWS

text: The injustice of his sentence was very flagrant; all Paris was indignant; and it was judged that his religion and wealth rather than the crime alleged against him had been the cause of his condemnation.
author: MWS

text: Felix had accidentally been present at the trial; his horror and indignation were uncontrollable when he heard the decision of the court.
author: MWS

text: He made at that moment a solemn vow to deliver him and then looked around for the means.
author: MWS

text: After many fruitless attempts to gain admittance to the prison he found a strongly grated window in an unguarded part of the building which lighted the dungeon of the unfortunate Muhammadan who loaded with chains waited in despair the execution of the barbarous sentence.
author: MWS

text: Felix visited the grate at night and made known to the prisoner his intentions in his favour.
author: MWS

text: The Turk amazed and delighted endeavoured to kindle the zeal of his deliverer by promises of reward and wealth.
author: MWS

text: Felix rejected his offers with contempt yet when he saw the lovely Safie who was allowed to visit her father and who by her gestures expressed her lively gratitude the youth could not help owning to his own mind that the captive possessed a treasure which would fully reward his toil and hazard.
author: MWS

text: The Turk quickly perceived the impression that his daughter had made on the heart of Felix and endeavoured to secure him more entirely in his interests by the promise of her hand in marriage so soon as he should be conveyed to a place of safety.
author: MWS

text: Felix was too delicate to accept this offer yet he looked forward to the probability of the event as to the consummation of his happiness.
author: MWS

text: During the ensuing days while the preparations were going forward for the escape of the merchant the zeal of Felix was warmed by several letters that he received from this lovely girl who found means to express her thoughts in the language of her lover by the aid of an old man a servant of her father who understood French.
author: MWS

text: She thanked him in the most ardent terms for his intended services towards her parent and at the same time she gently deplored her own fate.
author: MWS

text: I have copies of these letters for I found means during my residence in the hovel to procure the implements of writing; and the letters were often in the hands of Felix or Agatha.
author: MWS

text: Before I depart I will give them to you; they will prove the truth of my tale; but at present as the sun is already far declined I shall only have time to repeat the substance of them to you.
author: MWS

text: Safie related that her mother was a Christian Arab seized and made a slave by the Turks; recommended by her beauty she had won the heart of the father of Safie who married her.
author: MWS

text: The young girl spoke in high and enthusiastic terms of her mother who born in freedom spurned the bondage to which she was now reduced.
author: MWS

text: She instructed her daughter in the tenets of her religion and taught her to aspire to higher powers of intellect and an independence of spirit forbidden to the female followers of Muhammad.
author: MWS

text: This lady died but her lessons were indelibly impressed on the mind of Safie who sickened at the prospect of again returning to Asia and being immured within the walls of a harem allowed only to occupy herself with infantile amusements ill-suited to the temper of her soul now accustomed to grand ideas and a noble emulation for virtue.
author: MWS

text: The prospect of marrying a Christian and remaining in a country where women were allowed to take a rank in society was enchanting to her.
author: MWS

text: The day for the execution of the Turk was fixed but on the night previous to it he quitted his prison and before morning was distant many leagues from Paris.
author: MWS

text: Felix had procured passports in the name of his father sister and himself.
author: MWS

text: He had previously communicated his plan to the former who aided the deceit by quitting his house under the pretence of a journey and concealed himself with his daughter in an obscure part of Paris.
author: MWS

text: Felix conducted the fugitives through France to Lyons and across Mont Cenis to Leghorn where the merchant had decided to wait a favourable opportunity of passing into some part of the Turkish dominions.
author: MWS

text: Safie resolved to remain with her father until the moment of his departure before which time the Turk renewed his promise that she should be united to his deliverer; and Felix remained with them in expectation of that event; and in the meantime he enjoyed the society of the Arabian who exhibited towards him the simplest and tenderest affection.
author: MWS

text: They conversed with one another through the means of an interpreter and sometimes with the interpretation of looks; and Safie sang to him the divine airs of her native country.
author: MWS

text: The Turk allowed this intimacy to take place and encouraged the hopes of the youthful lovers while in his heart he had formed far other plans.
author: MWS

text: He loathed the idea that his daughter should be united to a Christian but he feared the resentment of Felix if he should appear lukewarm for he knew that he was still in the power of his deliverer if he should choose to betray him to the Italian state which they inhabited.
author: MWS

text: He revolved a thousand plans by which he should be enabled to prolong the deceit until it might be no longer necessary and secretly to take his daughter with him when he departed.
author: MWS

text: His plans were facilitated by the news which arrived from Paris.
author: MWS

text: The government of France were greatly enraged at the escape of their victim and spared no pains to detect and punish his deliverer.
author: MWS

text: The plot of Felix was quickly discovered and De Lacey and Agatha were thrown into prison.
author: MWS

text: The news reached Felix and roused him from his dream of pleasure.
author: MWS

text: His blind and aged father and his gentle sister lay in a noisome dungeon while he enjoyed the free air and the society of her whom he loved.
author: MWS

text: He quickly arranged with the Turk that if the latter should find a favourable opportunity for escape before Felix could return to Italy Safie should remain as a boarder at a convent at Leghorn; and then quitting the lovely Arabian he hastened to Paris and delivered himself up to the vengeance of the law hoping to free De Lacey and Agatha by this proceeding.
author: MWS

text: They remained confined for five months before the trial took place the result of which deprived them of their fortune and condemned them to a perpetual exile from their native country.
author: MWS

text: They found a miserable asylum in the cottage in Germany where I discovered them.
author: MWS

text: Felix soon learned that the treacherous Turk for whom he and his family endured such unheard-of oppression on discovering that his deliverer was thus reduced to poverty and ruin became a traitor to good feeling and honour and had quitted Italy with his daughter insultingly sending Felix a pittance of money to aid him as he said in some plan of future maintenance.
author: MWS

text: Such were the events that preyed on the heart of Felix and rendered him when I first saw him the most miserable of his family.
author: MWS

text: He could have endured poverty and while this distress had been the meed of his virtue he gloried in it; but the ingratitude of the Turk and the loss of his beloved Safie were misfortunes more bitter and irreparable.
author: MWS

text: The arrival of the Arabian now infused new life into his soul.
author: MWS

text: When the news reached Leghorn that Felix was deprived of his wealth and rank the merchant commanded his daughter to think no more of her lover but to prepare to return to her native country.
author: MWS

text: The generous nature of Safie was outraged by this command; she attempted to expostulate with her father but he left her angrily reiterating his tyrannical mandate.
author: MWS

text: A few days after the Turk entered his daughters apartment and told her hastily that he had reason to believe that his residence at Leghorn had been divulged and that he should speedily be delivered up to the French government; he had consequently hired a vessel to convey him to Constantinople for which city he should sail in a few hours.
author: MWS

text: He intended to leave his daughter under the care of a confidential servant to follow at her leisure with the greater part of his property which had not yet arrived at Leghorn.
author: MWS

text: When alone Safie resolved in her own mind the plan of conduct that it would become her to pursue in this emergency.
author: MWS

text: A residence in Turkey was abhorrent to her; her religion and her feelings were alike averse to it.
author: MWS

text: By some papers of her father which fell into her hands she heard of the exile of her lover and learnt the name of the spot where he then resided.
author: MWS

text: She hesitated some time but at length she formed her determination.
author: MWS

text: Taking with her some jewels that belonged to her and a sum of money she quitted Italy with an attendant a native of Leghorn but who understood the common language of Turkey and departed for Germany.
author: MWS

text: She arrived in safety at a town about twenty leagues from the cottage of De Lacey when her attendant fell dangerously ill.
author: MWS

text: Safie nursed her with the most devoted affection but the poor girl died and the Arabian was left alone unacquainted with the language of the country and utterly ignorant of the customs of the world.
author: MWS

text: The Italian had mentioned the name of the spot for which they were bound and after her death the woman of the house in which they had lived took care that Safie should arrive in safety at the cottage of her lover.
author: MWS

text: I learned from the views of social life which it developed to admire their virtues and to deprecate the vices of mankind.
author: MWS

text: As yet I looked upon crime as a distant evil benevolence and generosity were ever present before me inciting within me a desire to become an actor in the busy scene where so many admirable qualities were called forth and displayed.
author: MWS

text: But in giving an account of the progress of my intellect I must not omit a circumstance which occurred in the beginning of the month of August of the same year.
author: MWS

text: One night during my accustomed visit to the neighbouring wood where I collected my own food and brought home firing for my protectors I found on the ground a leathern portmanteau containing several articles of dress and some books.
author: MWS

text: I eagerly seized the prize and returned with it to my hovel.
author: MWS

text: Fortunately the books were written in the language the elements of which I had acquired at the cottage; they consisted of Paradise Lost a volume of Plutarchs Lives and the Sorrows of Werter.
author: MWS

text: The possession of these treasures gave me extreme delight; I now continually studied and exercised my mind upon these histories whilst my friends were employed in their ordinary occupations.
author: MWS

text: I can hardly describe to you the effect of these books.
author: MWS

text: They produced in me an infinity of new images and feelings that sometimes raised me to ecstasy but more frequently sunk me into the lowest dejection.
author: MWS

text: In the Sorrows of Werter besides the interest of its simple and affecting story so many opinions are canvassed and so many lights thrown upon what had hitherto been to me obscure subjects that I found in it a never-ending source of speculation and astonishment.
author: MWS

text: The gentle and domestic manners it described combined with lofty sentiments and feelings which had for their object something out of self accorded well with my experience among my protectors and with the wants which were for ever alive in my own bosom.
author: MWS

text: But I thought Werter himself a more divine being than I had ever beheld or imagined; his character contained no pretension but it sank deep.
author: MWS

text: The disquisitions upon death and suicide were calculated to fill  me with wonder.
author: MWS

text: I did not pretend to enter into the merits of the case yet I inclined towards the opinions of the hero whose extinction I wept without precisely understanding it.
author: MWS

text: As I read however I applied much personally to my own feelings and condition.
author: MWS

text: I found myself similar yet at the same time strangely unlike to the beings concerning whom I read and to whose conversation I was a listener.
author: MWS

text: I sympathised with and partly understood them but I was unformed in mind; I was dependent on none and related to none.
author: MWS

text: The path of my departure was free and there was none to lament my annihilation.
author: MWS

text: What did this mean  Who was I  What was I  Whence did I come  What was my destination  These questions continually recurred but I was unable to solve them.
author: MWS

text: The volume of Plutarchs Lives which I possessed contained the histories of the first founders of the ancient republics.
author: MWS

text: This book had a far different effect upon me from the Sorrows of Werter.
author: MWS

text: I learned from Werters imaginations despondency and gloom but Plutarch taught me high thoughts; he elevated me above the wretched sphere of my own reflections to admire and love the heroes of past ages.
author: MWS

text: I had a very confused knowledge of kingdoms wide extents of country mighty rivers and boundless seas.
author: MWS

text: But I was perfectly unacquainted with towns and large assemblages of men.
author: MWS

text: The cottage of my protectors had been the only school in which I had studied human nature but this book developed new and mightier scenes of action.
author: MWS

text: I read of men concerned in public affairs governing or massacring their species.
author: MWS

text: I felt the greatest ardour for virtue rise within me and abhorrence for vice as far as I understood the signification of those terms relative as they were as I applied them to pleasure and pain alone.
author: MWS

text: Induced by these feelings I was of course led to admire peaceable lawgivers Numa Solon and Lycurgus in preference to Romulus and Theseus.
author: MWS

text: The patriarchal lives of my protectors caused these impressions to take a firm hold on my mind; perhaps if my first introduction to humanity had been made by a young soldier burning for glory and slaughter I should have been imbued with different sensations.
author: MWS

text: But Paradise Lost excited different and far deeper emotions.
author: MWS

text: I read it as I had read the other volumes which had fallen into my hands as a true history.
author: MWS

text: It moved every feeling of wonder and awe that the picture of an omnipotent God warring with his creatures was capable of exciting.
author: MWS

text: I often referred the several situations as their similarity struck me to my own.
author: MWS

text: Like Adam I was apparently united by no link to any other being in existence; but his state was far different from mine in every other respect.
author: MWS

text: He had come forth from the hands of God a perfect creature happy and prosperous guarded by the especial care of his Creator; he was allowed to converse with and acquire knowledge from beings of a superior nature but I was wretched helpless and alone.
author: MWS

text: Many times I considered Satan as the fitter emblem of my condition for often like him when I viewed the bliss of my protectors the bitter gall of envy rose within me.
author: MWS

text: Soon after my arrival in the hovel I discovered some papers in the pocket of the dress which I had taken from your laboratory.
author: MWS

text: At first I had neglected them but now that I was able to decipher the characters in which they were written I began to study them with diligence.
author: MWS

text: It was your journal of the four months that preceded my creation.
author: MWS

text: You minutely described in these papers every step you took in the progress of your work; this history was mingled with accounts of domestic occurrences.
author: MWS

text: Everything is related in them which bears reference to my accursed origin; the whole detail of that series of disgusting circumstances which produced it is set in view; the minutest description of my odious and loathsome person is given in language which painted your own horrors and rendered mine indelible.
author: MWS

text: Accursed creator Why did you form a monster so hideous that even you turned from me in disgust  God in pity made man beautiful and alluring after his own image; but my form is a filthy type of yours more horrid even from the very resemblance.
author: MWS

text: Satan had his companions fellow devils to admire and encourage him but I am solitary and abhorred.
author: MWS

text: These were the reflections of my hours of despondency and solitude; but when I contemplated the virtues of the cottagers their amiable and benevolent dispositions I persuaded myself that when they should become acquainted with my admiration of their virtues they  would compassionate me and overlook my personal deformity.
author: MWS

text: Could they turn from their door one however monstrous who solicited their compassion and friendship  I resolved at least not to despair but in every way to fit myself for an interview with them which would decide my fate.
author: MWS

text: I postponed this attempt for some months longer for the importance attached to its success inspired me with a dread lest I should fail.
author: MWS

text: Besides I found that my understanding improved so much with every days experience that I was unwilling to commence this undertaking until a few more months should have added to my sagacity.
author: MWS

text: Several changes in the meantime took place in the cottage.
author: MWS

text: The presence of Safie diffused happiness among its inhabitants and I also found that a greater degree of plenty reigned there.
author: MWS

text: Felix and Agatha spent more time in amusement and conversation and were assisted in their labours by servants.
author: MWS

text: They did not appear rich but they were contented and happy; their feelings were serene and peaceful while mine became every day more tumultuous.
author: MWS

text: Increase of knowledge only discovered to me more clearly what a wretched outcast I was.
author: MWS

text: I cherished hope it is true but it vanished when I beheld my person reflected in water or my shadow in the moonshine even as that frail image and that inconstant shade.
author: MWS

text: I endeavoured to crush these fears and to fortify myself for the trial which in a few months I resolved to undergo; and sometimes I allowed my thoughts unchecked by reason to ramble in the fields of Paradise and dared to fancy amiable and lovely creatures sympathising with my feelings and cheering my gloom; their angelic countenances breathed smiles of consolation.
author: MWS

text: But it was all a dream; no Eve soothed my sorrows nor shared my thoughts; I was alone.
author: MWS

text: But where was mine  He had abandoned me and in the bitterness of my heart I cursed him.
author: MWS

text: I saw with surprise and grief the leaves decay and fall and nature again assume the barren and bleak appearance it had worn when I first beheld the woods and the lovely moon.
author: MWS

text: Yet I did not heed the bleakness of the weather; I was better fitted by my conformation for the endurance of cold than heat.
author: MWS

text: But my chief delights were the sight of the flowers the birds and all the gay apparel of summer; when those deserted me I turned with more attention towards the cottagers.
author: MWS

text: Their happiness was not decreased by the absence of summer.
author: MWS

text: They loved and sympathised with one another; and their joys depending on each other were not interrupted by the casualties that took place around them.
author: MWS

text: The more I saw of them the greater became my desire to claim their protection and kindness; my heart yearned to be known and loved by these amiable creatures; to see their sweet looks directed towards me with affection was the utmost limit of my ambition.
author: MWS

text: I dared not think that they would turn them from me with disdain and horror.
author: MWS

text: The poor that stopped at their door were never driven away.
author: MWS

text: I asked it is true for greater treasures than a little food or rest  I required kindness and sympathy; but I did not believe myself utterly unworthy of it.
author: MWS

text: The winter advanced and an entire revolution of the seasons had taken place since I awoke into life.
author: MWS

text: My attention at this time was solely directed towards my plan of introducing myself into the cottage of my protectors.
author: MWS

text: I revolved many projects but that on which I finally fixed was to enter the dwelling when the blind old man should be alone.
author: MWS

text: I had sagacity enough to discover that the unnatural hideousness of my person was the chief object of horror with those who had formerly beheld me.
author: MWS

text: My voice although harsh had nothing terrible in it; I thought therefore that if in the absence of his children I could gain the good will and mediation of the old De Lacey I might by his means be tolerated by my younger protectors.
author: MWS

text: One day when the sun shone on the red leaves that strewed the ground and diffused cheerfulness although it denied warmth Safie Agatha and Felix departed on a long country walk and the old man at his own desire was left alone in the cottage.
author: MWS

text: When his children had departed he took up his guitar and played several mournful but sweet airs more sweet and mournful than I had ever heard him play before.
author: MWS

text: At first his countenance was illuminated with pleasure but as he continued thoughtfulness and sadness succeeded; at length laying aside the instrument he sat absorbed in reflection.
author: MWS

text: My heart beat quick; this was the hour and moment of trial which would decide my hopes or realise my fears.
author: MWS

text: All was silent in and around the cottage; it was an excellent opportunity; yet when I proceeded to execute my plan my limbs failed me and I sank to the ground.
author: MWS

text: Again I rose and exerting all the firmness of which I was master removed the planks which I had placed before my hovel to conceal my retreat.
author: MWS

text: The fresh air revived me and with renewed determination I approached the door of their cottage.
author: MWS

text: Pardon this intrusion said I; I am a traveller in want of a little rest; you would greatly oblige me if you would allow me to remain a few minutes before the fire.
author: MWS

text: Enter said De Lacey and I will try in what manner I can to relieve your wants; but unfortunately my children are from home and as I am blind I am afraid I shall find it difficult to procure food for you.
author: MWS

text: Do not trouble yourself my kind host; I have food; it is warmth and rest only that I need.
author: MWS

text: I knew that every minute was precious to me yet I remained irresolute in what manner to commence the interview when the old man addressed me.
author: MWS

text: By your language stranger I suppose you are my countryman; are you French  No; but I was educated by a French family and understand that language only.
author: MWS

text: I am now going to claim the protection of some friends whom I sincerely love and of whose favour I have some hopes.
author: MWS

text: I am an unfortunate and deserted creature I look around and I have no relation or friend upon earth.
author: MWS

text: These amiable people to whom I go have never seen me and know little of me.
author: MWS

text: I am full of fears for if I fail there I am an outcast in the world for ever.
author: MWS

text: To be friendless is indeed to be unfortunate but the hearts of men when unprejudiced by any obvious self-interest are full of brotherly love and charity.
author: MWS

text: Rely therefore on your hopes; and if these friends are good and amiable do not despair.
author: MWS

text: They are kindthey are the most excellent creatures in the world; but unfortunately they are prejudiced against me.
author: MWS

text: I have good dispositions; my life has been hitherto harmless and in some degree beneficial; but a fatal prejudice clouds their eyes and where they ought to see a feeling and kind friend they behold only a detestable monster.
author: MWS

text: That is indeed unfortunate; but if you are really blameless cannot you undeceive them  I am about to undertake that task; and it is on that account that I feel so many overwhelming terrors.
author: MWS

text: I tenderly love these friends; I have unknown to them been for many months in the habits of daily kindness towards them; but they believe that I wish to injure them and it is that prejudice which I wish to overcome.
author: MWS

text: The old man paused and then continued If you will unreservedly confide to me the particulars of your tale I perhaps may be of use in undeceiving them.
author: MWS

text: I am blind and cannot judge of your countenance but there is something in your words which persuades me that you are sincere.
author: MWS

text: I am poor and an exile but it will afford me true pleasure to be in any way serviceable to a human creature.
author: MWS

text: Excellent man  I thank you and accept your generous offer.
author: MWS

text: You raise me from the dust by this kindness; and I trust that by your aid I shall not be driven from the society and sympathy of your fellow creatures.
author: MWS

text: Heaven forbid  Even if you were really criminal for that can only drive you to desperation and not instigate you to virtue.
author: MWS

text: I also am unfortunate; I and my family have been condemned although innocent; judge therefore if I do not feel for your misfortunes.
author: MWS

text: How can I thank you my best and only benefactor  From your lips first have I heard the voice of kindness directed towards me; I shall be for ever grateful; and your present humanity assures me of success with those friends whom I am on the point of meeting.
author: MWS

text: May I know the names and residence of those friends  I paused.
author: MWS

text: This I thought was the moment of decision which was to rob me of or bestow happiness on me for ever.
author: MWS

text: I struggled vainly for firmness sufficient to answer him but the effort destroyed all my remaining strength; I sank on the chair and sobbed aloud.
author: MWS

text: I had not a moment to lose but seizing the hand of the old man I cried Now is the time  Save and protect me  You and your family are the friends whom I seek.
author: MWS

text: Do not you desert me in the hour of trial  Great God exclaimed the old man.
author: MWS

text: Who are you  At that instant the cottage door was opened and Felix Safie and Agatha entered.
author: MWS

text: Who can describe their horror and consternation on beholding me  Agatha fainted and Safie unable to attend to her friend rushed out of the cottage.
author: MWS

text: Felix darted forward and with supernatural force tore me from his father to whose knees I clung in a transport of fury he dashed me to the ground and struck me violently with a stick.
author: MWS

text: I could have torn him limb from limb as the lion rends the antelope.
author: MWS

text: But my heart sank within me as with bitter sickness and I refrained.
author: MWS

text: I saw him on the point of repeating his blow when overcome by pain and anguish I quitted the cottage and in the general tumult escaped unperceived to my hovel.
author: MWS

text: Cursed cursed creator  Why did I live  Why in that instant did I not extinguish the spark of existence which you had so wantonly bestowed  I know not; despair had not yet taken possession of me; my feelings were those of rage and revenge.
author: MWS

text: I could with pleasure have destroyed the cottage and its inhabitants and have glutted myself with their shrieks and misery.
author: MWS

text: When night came I quitted my retreat and wandered in the wood; and now no longer restrained by the fear of discovery I gave vent to my anguish in fearful howlings.
author: MWS

text: I was like a wild beast that had broken the toils destroying the objects that obstructed me and ranging through the wood with a stag-like swiftness.
author: MWS

text: Oh  What a miserable night I passed  The cold stars shone in mockery and the bare trees waved their branches above me; now and then the sweet voice of a bird burst forth amidst the universal stillness.
author: MWS

text: All save I were at rest or in enjoyment; I like the arch-fiend bore a hell within me and finding myself unsympathised with wished to tear up the trees spread havoc and destruction around me and then to have sat down and enjoyed the ruin.
author: MWS

text: But this was a luxury of sensation that could not endure; I became fatigued with excess of bodily exertion and sank on the damp grass in the sick impotence of despair.
author: MWS

text: There was none among the myriads of men that existed who would pity or assist me; and should I feel kindness towards my enemies  No; from that moment I declared everlasting war against the species and more than all against him who had formed me and sent me forth to this insupportable misery.
author: MWS

text: The sun rose; I heard the voices of men and knew that it was impossible to return to my retreat during that day.
author: MWS

text: Accordingly I hid myself in some thick underwood determining to devote the ensuing hours to reflection on my situation.
author: MWS

text: The pleasant sunshine and the pure air of day restored me to some degree of tranquillity; and when I considered what had passed at the cottage I could not help believing that I had been too hasty in my conclusions.
author: MWS

text: It was apparent that my conversation had interested the father in my behalf and  I was a fool in having exposed my person to the horror of his children.
author: MWS

text: I ought to have familiarised the old De Lacey to me and by degrees to have discovered myself to the rest of his family when they should have been  prepared for my approach.
author: MWS

text: But I did not believe my errors to be irretrievable and after much consideration I resolved to return to the cottage seek the old man and by my representations win him to my party.
author: MWS

text: These thoughts calmed me and in the afternoon I sank into a profound sleep; but the fever of my blood did not allow me to be visited by peaceful dreams.
author: MWS

text: The horrible scene of the preceding day was for ever acting before my eyes; the females were flying and the enraged Felix tearing me from his fathers feet.
author: MWS

text: I awoke exhausted and finding that it was already night I crept forth from my hiding-place and went in search of food.
author: MWS

text: When my hunger was appeased I directed my steps towards the well-known path that conducted to the cottage.
author: MWS

text: I crept into my hovel and remained in silent expectation of the accustomed hour when the family arose.
author: MWS

text: That hour passed the sun mounted high in the heavens but the cottagers did not appear.
author: MWS

text: The inside of the cottage was dark and I heard no motion; I cannot describe the agony of this suspense.
author: MWS

text: Presently two countrymen passed by but pausing near the cottage they entered into conversation using violent gesticulations; but I did not understand what they said as they spoke the language of the country which differed from that of my protectors.
author: MWS

text: Soon after however Felix approached with another man; I was surprised as I knew that he had not quitted the cottage that morning and waited anxiously to discover from his discourse the meaning of these unusual appearances.
author: MWS

text: Do you consider said his companion to him that you will be obliged to pay three months rent and to lose the produce of your garden I do not wish to take any unfair advantage and I beg therefore that you will take some days to consider of your determination.
author: MWS

text: It is utterly useless replied Felix; we can never again inhabit your cottage.
author: MWS

text: The life of my father is in the greatest danger owing to the dreadful circumstance that I have related.
author: MWS

text: My wife and my sister will never recover from their horror.
author: MWS

text: Take possession of your tenement and let me fly from this place.
author: MWS

text: He and his companion entered the cottage in which they remained for a few minutes and then departed.
author: MWS

text: I continued for the remainder of the day in my hovel in a state of utter and stupid despair.
author: MWS

text: My protectors had departed and had broken the only link that held me to the world.
author: MWS

text: For the first time the feelings of revenge and hatred filled my bosom and I did not strive to control them but allowing myself to be borne away by the stream I bent my mind towards injury and death.
author: MWS

text: When I thought of my friends of the mild voice of De Lacey the gentle eyes of Agatha and the exquisite beauty of the Arabian these thoughts vanished and a gush of tears somewhat soothed me.
author: MWS

text: But again when I reflected that they had spurned and deserted me anger returned a rage of anger and unable to injure anything human I turned my fury towards inanimate objects.
author: MWS

text: As night advanced I placed a variety of combustibles around the cottage and after having destroyed every vestige of cultivation in the garden I waited with forced impatience until the moon had sunk to commence my operations.
author: MWS

text: As the night advanced a fierce wind arose from the woods and quickly dispersed the clouds that had loitered in the heavens; the blast tore along like a mighty avalanche and produced a kind of insanity in my spirits that burst all bounds of reason and reflection.
author: MWS

text: I lighted the dry branch of a tree and danced with fury around the devoted cottage my eyes still fixed on the western horizon the edge of which the moon nearly touched.
author: MWS

text: A part of its orb was at length hid and I waved my brand; it sank and with a loud scream I fired the straw and heath and bushes which I had collected.
author: MWS

text: The wind fanned the fire and the cottage was quickly enveloped by the flames which clung to it and licked it with their forked and destroying tongues.
author: MWS

text: As soon as I was convinced that no assistance could save any part of the habitation I quitted the scene and sought for refuge in the woods.
author: MWS

text: And now with the world before me whither should I bend my steps  I resolved to fly far from the scene of my misfortunes; but to me hated and despised every country must be equally horrible.
author: MWS

text: I learned from your papers that you were my father my creator; and to whom could I apply with more fitness than to him who had given me life  Among the lessons that Felix had bestowed upon Safie geography had not been omitted; I had learned from these the relative situations of the different countries of the earth.
author: MWS

text: You had mentioned Geneva as the name of your native town and towards this place I resolved to proceed.
author: MWS

text: But how was I to direct myself  I knew that I must travel in a southwesterly direction to reach my destination but the sun was my only guide.
author: MWS

text: I did not know the names of the towns that I was to pass through nor could I ask information from a single human being; but I did not despair.
author: MWS

text: From you only could I hope for succour although towards you I felt no sentiment but that of hatred.
author: MWS

text: Unfeeling heartless creator  You had endowed me with perceptions and passions and then cast me abroad an object for the scorn and horror of mankind.
author: MWS

text: But on you only had I any claim for pity and redress and from you I determined to seek that justice which I vainly attempted to gain from any other being that wore the human form.
author: MWS

text: My travels were long and the sufferings I endured intense.
author: MWS

text: It was late in autumn when I quitted the district where I had so long resided.
author: MWS

text: I travelled only at night fearful of encountering the visage of a human being.
author: MWS

text: Nature decayed around me and the sun became heatless; rain and snow poured around me; mighty rivers were frozen; the surface of the earth was hard and chill and bare and I found no shelter.
author: MWS

text: Oh earth  How often did I imprecate curses on the cause of my being  The mildness of my nature had fled and all within me was turned to gall and bitterness.
author: MWS

text: The nearer I approached to your habitation the more deeply did I feel the spirit of revenge enkindled in my heart.
author: MWS

text: Snow fell and the waters were hardened but I rested not.
author: MWS

text: A few incidents now and then directed me and I possessed a map of the country; but I often wandered wide from my path.
author: MWS

text: The agony of my feelings allowed me no respite; no incident occurred from which my rage and misery could not extract its food; but a circumstance that happened when I arrived on the confines of Switzerland when the sun had recovered its warmth and the earth again began to look green confirmed in an especial manner the bitterness and horror of my feelings.
author: MWS

text: I generally rested during the day and travelled only when I was secured by night from the view of man.
author: MWS

text: One morning however finding that my path lay through a deep wood I ventured to continue my journey after the sun had risen; the day which was one of the first of spring cheered even me by the loveliness of its sunshine and the balminess of the air.
author: MWS

text: I felt emotions of gentleness and pleasure that had long appeared dead revive within me.
author: MWS

text: Half surprised by the novelty of these sensations I allowed myself to be borne away by them and forgetting my solitude and deformity dared to be happy.
author: MWS

text: Soft tears again bedewed my cheeks and I even raised my humid eyes with thankfulness towards the blessed sun which bestowed such joy upon me.
author: MWS

text: I continued to wind among the paths of the wood until I came to its boundary which was skirted by a deep and rapid river into which many of the trees bent their branches now budding with the fresh spring.
author: MWS

text: Here I paused not exactly knowing what path to pursue when I heard the sound of voices that induced me to conceal myself under the shade of a cypress.
author: MWS

text: I was scarcely hid when a young girl came running towards the spot where I was concealed laughing as if she ran from someone in sport.
author: MWS

text: She continued her course along the precipitous sides of the river when suddenly her foot slipped and she fell into the rapid stream.
author: MWS

text: I rushed from my hiding-place and with extreme labour from the force of the current saved her and dragged her to shore.
author: MWS

text: She was senseless and I endeavoured by every means in my power to restore animation when I was suddenly interrupted by the approach of a rustic who was probably the person from whom she had playfully fled.
author: MWS

text: London was our present point of rest; we determined to remain several months in this wonderful and celebrated city.

text: Clerval desired the intercourse of the men of genius and talent who flourished at this time but this was with me a secondary object; I was principally occupied with the means of obtaining the information necessary for the completion of my promise and quickly availed myself of the letters of introduction that I had brought with me addressed to the most distinguished natural philosophers.
author: MWS

text: If this journey had taken place during my days of study and happiness it would have afforded me inexpressible pleasure.
author: MWS

text: But a blight had come over my existence and I only visited these people for the sake of the information they might give me on the subject in which my interest was so terribly profound.
author: MWS

text: Company was irksome to me; when alone I could fill my mind with the sights of heaven and earth; the voice of Henry soothed me and I could thus cheat myself into a transitory peace.
author: MWS

text: But busy uninteresting joyous faces brought back despair to my heart.
author: MWS

text: I saw an insurmountable barrier placed between me and my fellow men; this barrier was sealed with the blood of William and Justine and to reflect on the events connected with those names filled my soul with anguish.
author: MWS

text: But in Clerval I saw the image of my former self; he was inquisitive and anxious to gain experience and instruction.
author: MWS

text: The difference of manners which he observed was to him an inexhaustible source of instruction and amusement.
author: MWS

text: He was also pursuing an object he had long had in view.
author: MWS

text: His design was to visit India in the belief that he had in his knowledge of its various languages and in the views he had taken of its society the means of materially assisting the progress of European colonization and trade.
author: MWS

text: In Britain only could he further the execution of his plan.
author: MWS

text: He was for ever busy and the only check to his enjoyments was my sorrowful and dejected mind.
author: MWS

text: I tried to conceal this as much as possible that I might not debar him from the pleasures natural to one who was entering on a new scene of life undisturbed by any care or bitter recollection.

text: I often refused to accompany him alleging another engagement that I might remain alone.
author: MWS

text: I now also began to collect the materials necessary for my new creation and this was to me like the torture of single drops of water continually falling on the head.
author: MWS

text: Every thought that was devoted to it was an extreme anguish and every word that I spoke in allusion to it caused my lips to quiver and my heart to palpitate.
author: MWS

text: After passing some months in London we received a letter from a person in Scotland who had formerly been our visitor at Geneva.
author: MWS

text: He mentioned the beauties of his native country and asked us if those were not sufficient allurements to induce us to prolong our journey as far north as Perth where he resided.
author: MWS

text: Clerval eagerly desired to accept this invitation and I although I abhorred society wished to view again mountains and streams and all the wondrous works with which Nature adorns her chosen dwelling-places.  We had arrived in England at the beginning of October and it was now February.
author: MWS

text: We accordingly determined to commence our journey towards the north at the expiration of another month.
author: MWS

text: In this expedition we did not intend to follow the great road to Edinburgh but to visit Windsor Oxford Matlock and the Cumberland lakes resolving to arrive at the completion of this tour about the end of July.
author: MWS

text: I packed up my chemical instruments and the materials I had collected resolving to finish my labours in some obscure nook in the northern highlands of Scotland.
author: MWS

text: We quitted London on the 27th of March and remained a few days at Windsor rambling in its beautiful forest.
author: MWS

text: This was a new scene to us mountaineers; the majestic oaks the quantity of game and the herds of stately deer were all novelties to us.
author: MWS

text: As we entered this city our minds were filled with the remembrance of the events that had been transacted there more than a century and a half before.
author: MWS

text: It was here that Charles I. had collected his forces.

text: This city had remained faithful to him after the whole nation had forsaken his cause to join the standard of Parliament and liberty.
author: MWS

text: The memory of that unfortunate king and his companions the amiable Falkland the insolent Goring his queen and son gave a peculiar interest to every part of the city which they might be supposed to have inhabited.
author: MWS

text: The spirit of elder days found a dwelling here and we delighted to trace its footsteps.
author: MWS

author: MWS

text: I enjoyed this scene and yet my enjoyment was embittered both by the memory of the past and the anticipation of the future.
author: MWS

text: During my youthful days discontent never visited my mind and if I was ever overcome by ennui the sight of what is beautiful in nature or the study of what is excellent and sublime in the productions of man could always interest my heart and communicate elasticity to my spirits.

text: We passed a considerable period at Oxford rambling among its environs and endeavouring to identify every spot which might relate to the most animating epoch of English history.

text: Our little voyages of discovery were often prolonged by the successive objects that presented themselves.

text: We visited the tomb of the illustrious Hampden and the field on which that patriot fell.
author: MWS

text: For a moment my soul was elevated from its debasing and miserable fears to contemplate the divine ideas of liberty and self-sacrifice of which these sights were the monuments and the remembrancers.

text: For an instant I dared to shake off my chains and look around me with a free and lofty spirit but the iron had eaten into my flesh and I sank again trembling and hopeless into my miserable self.

text: I could now almost fancy myself among the Swiss mountains.

text: The little patches of snow which yet lingered on the northern sides of the mountains the lakes and the dashing of the rocky streams were all familiar and dear sights to me.

text: Here also we made some acquaintances who almost contrived to cheat me into happiness.

text: The delight of Clerval was proportionably greater than mine; his mind expanded in the company of men of talent and he found in his own nature greater capacities and resources than he could have imagined himself to have possessed while he associated with his inferiors.
author: MWS

text: I could pass my life here said he to me; and among these mountains I should scarcely regret Switzerland and the Rhine.

author: MWS

text: His feelings are for ever on the stretch; and when he begins to sink into repose he finds himself obliged to quit that on which he rests in pleasure for something new which again engages his attention and which also he forsakes for other novelties.
author: MWS

text: We had scarcely visited the various lakes of Cumberland and Westmorland and conceived an affection for some of the inhabitants when the period of our appointment with our Scotch friend approached and we left them to travel on.

text: I had now neglected my promise for some time and I feared the effects of the dmons disappointment.

text: He might remain in Switzerland and wreak his vengeance on my relatives.
author: MWS

text: This idea pursued me and tormented me at every moment from which I might otherwise have snatched repose and peace.
author: MWS

text: I waited for my letters with feverish impatience; if they were delayed I was miserable and overcome by a thousand fears; and when they arrived and I saw the superscription of Elizabeth or my father I hardly dared to read and ascertain my fate.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I thought that the fiend followed me and might expedite my remissness by murdering my companion.
author: MWS

text: When these thoughts possessed me I would not quit Henry for a moment but followed him as his shadow to protect him from the fancied rage of his destroyer.
author: MWS

text: I felt as if I had committed some great crime the consciousness of which haunted me.
author: MWS

text: I was guiltless but I had indeed drawn down a horrible curse upon my head as mortal as that of crime.
author: MWS

text: I visited Edinburgh with languid eyes and mind; and yet that city might have interested the most unfortunate being.
author: MWS

text: Clerval did not like it so well as Oxford for the antiquity of the latter city was more pleasing to him.
author: MWS

text: But the beauty and regularity of the new town of Edinburgh its romantic castle and its environs the most delightful in the world Arthurs Seat St. Bernards Well and the Pentland Hills compensated him for the change and filled him with cheerfulness and admiration.
author: MWS

text: We left Edinburgh in a week passing through Coupar St. Andrews and along the banks of the Tay to Perth where our friend expected us.
author: MWS

text: But I was in no mood to laugh and talk with strangers or enter into their feelings or plans with the good humour expected from a guest; and accordingly I told Clerval that I wished to make the tour of Scotland alone.
author: MWS

text: Do you said I enjoy yourself and let this be our rendezvous.
author: MWS

text: I may be absent a month or two; but do not interfere with my motions I entreat you; leave me to peace and solitude for a short time; and when I return I hope it will be with a lighter heart more congenial to your own temper.
author: MWS

text: Henry wished to dissuade me but seeing me bent on this plan ceased to remonstrate.
author: MWS

text: I had rather be with you he said in your solitary rambles than with these Scotch people whom I do not know; hasten then my dear  friend to return that I may again feel myself somewhat at home which I cannot do in your absence.
author: MWS

text: Having parted from my friend I determined to visit some remote spot of Scotland and finish my work in solitude.
author: MWS

text: I did not doubt but that the monster followed me and would discover himself to me when I should have finished that he might receive his companion.
author: MWS

text: With this resolution I traversed the northern highlands and fixed on one of the remotest of the Orkneys as the scene of my labours.
author: MWS

text: It was a place fitted for such a work being hardly more than a rock whose high sides were continually beaten upon by the waves.
author: MWS

text: The soil was barren scarcely affording pasture for a few miserable cows and oatmeal for its inhabitants which consisted of five persons whose gaunt and scraggy limbs gave tokens of their miserable fare.
author: MWS

text: Vegetables and bread when they indulged in such luxuries and even fresh water was to be procured from the mainland which was about five miles distant.
author: MWS

text: On the whole island there were but three miserable huts and one of these was vacant when I arrived.
author: MWS

text: It contained but two rooms and these exhibited all the squalidness of the most miserable penury.
author: MWS

text: The thatch had fallen in the walls were unplastered and the door was off its hinges.
author: MWS

text: I ordered it to be repaired bought some furniture and took possession an incident which would doubtless have occasioned some surprise had not all the senses of the cottagers been benumbed by want and squalid poverty.
author: MWS

text: As it was I lived ungazed at and unmolested hardly thanked for the pittance of food and clothes which I gave so much does suffering blunt even the coarsest sensations of men.
author: MWS

text: In this retreat I devoted the morning to labour; but in the evening when the weather permitted I walked on the stony beach of the sea to listen to the waves as they roared and dashed at my feet.
author: MWS

text: I thought of Switzerland; it was far different from this desolate and appalling landscape.
author: MWS

text: Its hills are covered with vines and its cottages are scattered thickly in the plains.
author: MWS

text: Its fair lakes reflect a blue and gentle sky and when troubled by the winds their tumult is but as the play of a lively infant when compared to the roarings of the giant ocean.
author: MWS

text: In this manner I distributed my occupations when I first arrived but as I proceeded in my labour it became every day more horrible and irksome to me.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I could not prevail on myself to enter my laboratory for several days and at other times I toiled day and night in order to complete my work.
author: MWS

text: During my first experiment a kind of enthusiastic frenzy had blinded me to the horror of my employment; my mind was intently fixed on the consummation of my labour and my eyes were shut to the horror of my proceedings.
author: MWS

text: But now I went to it in cold blood and my heart often sickened at the work of my hands.
author: MWS

text: Thus situated employed in the most detestable occupation immersed in a solitude where nothing could for an instant call my attention from the actual scene in which I was engaged my spirits became unequal; I grew restless and nervous.
author: MWS

text: Sometimes I sat with my eyes fixed on the ground fearing to raise them lest they should encounter the object which I so much dreaded to behold.
author: MWS

text: I feared to wander from the sight of my fellow creatures lest when alone he should come to claim his companion.
author: MWS

text: In the mean time I worked on and my labour was already considerably advanced.
author: MWS

text: I looked towards its completion with a tremulous and eager hope which I dared not trust myself to question but which was intermixed with obscure forebodings of evil that made my heart sicken in my bosom.
author: MWS

text: I sat one evening in my laboratory; the sun had set and the moon was just rising from the sea; I had not sufficient light for my employment and I remained idle in a pause of consideration of whether I should leave my labour for the night or hasten its conclusion by an unremitting attention to it.
author: MWS

text: As I sat a train of reflection occurred to me which led me to consider the effects of what I was now doing.
author: MWS

text: Three years before I was engaged in the same manner and had created a fiend whose unparalleled barbarity had desolated my heart and filled it for ever with the bitterest remorse.
author: MWS

text: I was now about to form another being of whose dispositions I was alike ignorant; she might become ten thousand times more malignant than her mate and delight for its own sake in murder and wretchedness.
author: MWS

text: He had sworn to quit the neighbourhood of man and hide himself in deserts but she had not; and she who in all probability was to become a thinking and reasoning animal might refuse to comply with a compact made before her creation.
author: MWS

text: They might even hate each other; the creature who already lived loathed his own deformity and might he not conceive a greater abhorrence for it when it came before his eyes in the female form She also might turn with disgust from him to the superior beauty of man; she might quit him and he be again alone exasperated by the fresh provocation of being deserted by one of his own species.
author: MWS

text: Even if they were to leave Europe and inhabit the deserts of the new world yet one of the first results of those sympathies for which the dmon thirsted would be children and a race of devils would be propagated upon the earth who might make the very existence of the species of man a condition precarious and full of terror.
author: MWS

text: Had I right for my own benefit to inflict this curse upon everlasting generations I had before been moved by the sophisms of the being I had created; I had been struck senseless by his fiendish threats; but now for the first time the wickedness of my promise burst upon me; I shuddered to think that future ages might curse me as their pest whose selfishness had not hesitated to buy its own peace at the price perhaps of the existence of the whole human race.
author: MWS

text: I trembled and my heart failed within me when on looking up I saw by the light of the moon the dmon at the casement.
author: MWS

text: A ghastly grin wrinkled his lips as he gazed on me where I sat fulfilling the task which he had allotted to me.
author: MWS

text: Yes he had followed me in my travels; he had loitered in forests hid himself in caves or taken refuge in wide and desert heaths; and he now came to mark my progress and claim the fulfilment of my promise.
author: MWS

text: As I looked on him his countenance expressed the utmost extent of malice and treachery.
author: MWS

text: I thought with a sensation of madness on my promise of creating another like to him and trembling with passion tore to pieces the thing on which I was engaged.
author: MWS

text: The wretch saw me destroy the creature on whose future existence he depended for happiness and with a howl of devilish despair and revenge withdrew.
author: MWS

text: I left the room and locking the door made a solemn vow in my own heart never to resume my labours; and then with trembling steps I sought my own apartment.
author: MWS

text: I was alone; none were near me to dissipate the gloom and relieve me from the sickening oppression of the most terrible reveries.
author: MWS

text: Several hours passed and I remained near my window gazing on the sea; it was almost motionless for the winds were hushed and all nature reposed under the eye of the quiet moon.
author: MWS

text: A few fishing vessels alone specked the water and now and then the gentle breeze wafted the sound of voices as the fishermen called to one another.
author: MWS

text: I felt the silence although I was hardly conscious of its extreme profundity until my ear was suddenly arrested by the paddling of oars near the shore and a person landed close to my house.
author: MWS

text: In a few minutes after I heard the creaking of my door as if some one endeavoured to open it softly.
author: MWS

text: I trembled from head to foot; I felt a presentiment of who it was and wished to rouse one of the peasants who dwelt in a cottage not far from mine; but I was overcome by the sensation of helplessness so often felt in frightful dreams when you in vain endeavour to fly from an impending danger and was rooted to the spot.
author: MWS

text: Presently I heard the sound of footsteps along the passage; the door opened and the wretch whom I dreaded appeared.
author: MWS

text: Shutting the door he approached me and said in a smothered voice  You have destroyed the work which you began; what is it that you intend Do you dare to break your promise I have endured toil and misery; I left Switzerland with you; I crept along the shores of the Rhine among its willow islands and over the summits of its hills.
author: MWS

text: I have dwelt many months in the heaths of England and among the deserts of Scotland.
author: MWS

text: I have endured incalculable fatigue and cold and hunger; do you dare destroy my hopes  Begone  I do break my promise; never will I create another like yourself equal in deformity and wickedness.
author: MWS

text: Slave I before reasoned with you but you have proved yourself unworthy of my condescension.
author: MWS

text: Remember that I have power; you believe yourself miserable but I can make you so wretched that the light of day will be hateful to you.
author: MWS

text: You are my creator but I am your master; obey  The hour of my irresolution is past and the period of your power is arrived.
author: MWS

text: Your threats cannot move me to do an act of wickedness; but they confirm me in a determination of not creating you a companion in vice.
author: MWS

text: Shall I in cool blood set loose upon the earth a dmon whose delight is in death and wretchedness  Begone  I am firm and your words will only exasperate my rage.
author: MWS

text: The monster saw my determination in my face and gnashed his teeth in the impotence of anger.
author: MWS

text: Shall each man cried he find a wife for his bosom and each beast have his mate and I be alone I had feelings of affection and they were requited by detestation and scorn.
author: MWS

text: Man You may hate but beware Your hours will pass in dread and misery and soon the bolt will fall which must ravish from you your happiness for ever.
author: MWS

text: Are you to be happy while I grovel in the intensity of my wretchedness You can blast my other passions but revenge remainsrevenge henceforth dearer than light or food I may die but first you my tyrant and tormentor shall curse the sun that gazes on your misery.
author: MWS

text: I will watch with the wiliness of a snake that I may sting with its venom.
author: MWS

text: Man you shall repent of the injuries you inflict.
author: MWS

text: Devil cease; and do not poison the air with these sounds of malice.
author: MWS

text: I have declared my resolution to you and I am no coward to bend beneath words.
author: MWS

text: I go; but remember I shall be with you on your wedding-night.  I started forward and exclaimed Villain  Before you sign my death-warrant be sure that you are yourself safe.

author: MWS

text: All was again silent but his words rang in my ears.

text: I burned with rage to pursue the murderer of my peace and precipitate him into the ocean.
author: MWS

text: I walked up and down my room hastily and perturbed while my imagination conjured up a thousand images to torment and sting me.

text: I shuddered to think who might be the next victim sacrificed to his insatiate revenge.

text: The prospect did not move me to fear; yet when I thought of my beloved Elizabeth of her tears and endless sorrow when she should find her lover so barbarously snatched from her tears the first I had shed for many months streamed from my eyes and I resolved not to fall before my enemy without a bitter struggle.
author: MWS

text: The night passed away and the sun rose from the ocean; my feelings became calmer if it may be called calmness when the violence of rage sinks into the depths of despair.
author: MWS

text: I left the house the horrid scene of the last nights contention and walked on the beach of the sea which I almost regarded as an insuperable barrier between me and my fellow creatures; nay a wish that such should prove the fact stole across me.
author: MWS

text: I desired that I might pass my life on that barren rock wearily it is true but uninterrupted by any sudden shock of misery.
author: MWS

text: If I returned it was to be sacrificed or to see those whom I most loved die under the grasp of a dmon whom I had myself created.
author: MWS

text: I walked about the isle like a restless spectre separated from all it loved and miserable in the separation.
author: MWS

text: When it became noon and the sun rose higher I lay down on the grass and was overpowered by a deep sleep.
author: MWS

text: I had been awake the whole of the preceding night my nerves were agitated and my eyes inflamed by watching and misery.
author: MWS

text: The sleep into which I now sank refreshed me; and when I awoke I again felt as if I belonged to a race of human beings like myself and I began to reflect upon what had passed with greater composure; yet still the words of the fiend rang in my ears like a death-knell; they appeared like a dream yet distinct and oppressive as a reality.
